Dear Ms. Borja:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 17-20, 24-26, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(1)(b) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation that the foster parent was willing to accept the foster child before the
child was placed in the foster home.
(1)(f) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the foster parent
received orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency after the child was
placed in the foster home. The child was placed in the foster home on January 6,
2020 and the foster parent received orientation on January 10, 2020.
(1)(g) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation that the foster parent received a copy of the foster parent/agency
agreement signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (1)(g) —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP
approved September 18, 2018.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the updated service plan
(USP) was not completed timely.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on November 14, 2019 and it
was completed on November 20, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on November 5, 2019 and it
was completed on December 5, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
MCL 722.112 722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster
family group home, child care center, group child care
home, and family child care home; individual certified in
first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation; applicability of
MCL 722.125.
Sec. 2a. (1) A child caring institution, foster family home, foster
family group home, child care center, group child care home,
and family child care home shall have individuals present, as
prescribed in the appropriate administrative rules, who have
current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation obtained through the American Red Cross, the
American Heart Association, or an equivalent organization or
institution approved by the department.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that the
foster parent has current certification in cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
September 18, 2018. This repeat violation was cited under R 400.12312 (4) Foster
parent training for first aid training.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.

MDHHS Policy Personnel Training.
SRM 200
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required to be taken
within six months of working in a position with child welfare
criminal record history information (CW-CHRI) access and every
two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes SAT timely.
Since the last inspection, there were 12 employees with access to criminal record
history information (CHRI). Based on a review of LMS transcripts for employees, six
current employees and one former employee were found to be in non-compliance of
timely certification of SAT.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
September 18, 2018.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
 Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six
months thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home
placement at age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition
meeting must be held within 30 calendar days of the
removal date.
Documentation
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan,
and any recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
6

In four out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, FTMs were not completed
timely.
 For one foster child’s record, an activity report for the April 15, 2020 FTM
was not completed. A FTM for case service plan reassessment did not occur
within 30 calendar days of the report due date of July 18, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, FTMs for case service plan reassessment did
not occur within 30 calendar days of the report due dates of November 5,
2019 and February 3, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the semi-annual transition meeting was not
completed within 30 calendar days of the removal date and every six months
thereafter. The foster child entered care on November 8, 2019 and a semi-
annual transition meeting was completed on July 30, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the semi-annual transition meeting was not
completed within 30 calendar days of the removal date and every six months
thereafter. The foster child entered care on July 18, 2018 and semi-annual
transition meetings were completed on March 19, 2019 and August 4, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
September 18, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
 Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
• Foster care worker.
• CPS worker.
• Adoption worker.
• Permanency resource monitors.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling/child face-to-face contacts.
7

In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, face-to-face contacts were
not entered in MiSACWIS within 5 business days of the contact.
 For one foster child’s record, the July 14, 2020 face-to-face contact with the
foster child and the caregiver was entered in MiSACWIS on August 25, 2020.
The July 24, 2020 sibling visit was entered in MiSACWIS on August 25, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the April 30, 2020 face-to-face contact with the
birth mother was entered in MiSACWIS on August 25, 2020. The contact with
the incarcerated birth father for report period April 8, 2020 to July 2, 2020 was
completed on June 18, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on August 25,
2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver for report period November 6, 2019 to February 3, 2020 was
completed on December 19, 2019 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on
August 26, 2020. The May 25, 2020 contact with the birth parents was
entered in MiSACWIS on August 26, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Caregivers.
FOM 722-06H
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than
one caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, face-to-face contacts with the
secondary caregiver in the home were not completed at least once each quarter.
There were no contacts with the secondary caregiver for reporting periods February
4, 2020 to May 3, 2020 and May 4, 2020 to August 1, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-face contacts must be
used to discuss the following:
 Petition and court orders.
8

 Case service plan.
 Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
 Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which there was parent
involvement, there was no face-to-face contact with the birth father in October 2019.
DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time. For the purposes of visitation only, siblings
include children related through birth, adoption, or marriage and
include siblings as defined by the American Indian or Alaskan
Native child's tribal code or custom. A sibling relationship
continues after termination of parental rights or when a marriage
ends by death or divorce.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which siblings were not
placed together, all of the monthly sibling visits were not completed. There were no
sibling visits in October 2019, January 2020, March 2020, April 2020, and May 2020.
DHHS Policy Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722-08C Agreement.
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent(s), foster parents/caregivers, and children 14
years and older.
9

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the birth parent and caregiver
did not sign the PATP for report period August 8, 2019 to November 5, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
FOM 722-08E
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure, using the DHS 69 Foster Care/Juvenile
Justice Action Summary, the caseworker must document:
 Reason for program/case closure.
 Reason the current program type continues to be
appropriate, if the child had multiple open programs and
one program has closed while the other remains open.
 How and when information related to the care and
supervision of the child or program/case closure was
shared with relevant parties.
 Information given to parent(s), guardian, or youth age 18
or older at program/case closure
The caseworker must document all case service delivery from
the report period end date of the previous case service plan
through the program or case closure date, including:
 A summary of services that were provided during care.
 A summary of services currently being provided.
 A list of services and needs still to be met and provisions
for follow up services, if any.
The caseworker must document whether:
 Medical information was given to the parents or next
placement and the date provided.
 Educational information was given to the parents or next
placement and the date provided.
 Closure was explained to all parties.
In one out of three closed foster children’s records reviewed, the DHS 69 Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary form was not completed within three
business days of the case closure. The foster care case closed on March 11, 2020
and the DHS 69 was completed on August 25, 2020.
DHHS Policy Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
FOM 722-09
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
10

In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all of the USPs were not
reviewed and approved within fourteen calendar days of the report date.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was completed on July 27, 2020 and it
was approved on August 13, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was completed on July 18, 2020 and it
was approved on August 17, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was completed on January 9, 2020 and
it was approved on January 28, 2020.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
provider receives the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passport was not
provided to the child’s foster care provider/parent or signed by the current foster care
worker per the timeframes specified in the policy.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated and
signed quarterly. The foster child was placed in the home on August 20,
2019. The caregiver signed the medical passport on November 15, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated and
signed quarterly. The foster child was placed in the home from April 1, 2019
to July 1, 2020. The caregiver signed the medical passport on August 7,
2019, February 25, 2020, and August 19, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated and
signed quarterly. The foster child was placed in the home on December
20,2018. The caregiver signed the medical passport on August 17, 2020.
11

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
September 18, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
November 13, 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on September 17, 2018 for the Renewal Inspection
that was completed in August 2018. The CAP was approved on September 18,
2018. The agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency
received the following repeat violations during the current Renewal Inspection:
 MCL 722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster family group
home, child care center, group child care home, and family child care home;
individual certified in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation; applicability of
MCL 722.125. This repeat violation was cited under R 400.12312 (4) Foster
parent training for first aid training.
 R 400.12326 (1) (g) Borrowed home
 MDHHS Policy SRM 200 Personnel Training
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
The agency submitted a CAP on November 13, 2019 for the Interim Inspection that
was completed in October 2019. The CAP was approved on November 13, 2019.
The agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received
the following repeat violations during the current Renewal Inspection:
 MCL 722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster family group
home, child care center, group child care home, and family child care home;
individual certified in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation; applicability of
MCL 722.125.
 R 400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans
12

 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contact with Caregivers
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and
Service Agreement
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
